Description:
Systems Biology to Identify Biomarkers of Neonatal Vaccine Immunogenicity

Project Number: AI118608

Grant PI: Ofer Levy, MD, PhD

Researchers are utilizing powerful omics tools to investigate the neonatal immune response to Hepatitis B vaccination in order to better understand vaccine-induced molecular pathways that underlie protective immunogenicity as correlates of protection
Shared Studies: SDY1256 Small Sample- Big Data: The Gambia

Data Center:
Center for Infectious Diseases

Seattle Biomedical Research Institute
Description:
Immune Responses to Malaria and HIV Infection and Immunization

Project Number: AI128914

Researchers are supporting identification of immune profiles that correlate with vaccine efficacy and are of potential relevance to protection against HIV-1 and P. falciparum (Malaria) infection.

Immune Profile And Network Analysis Of Malaria Infection And Vaccination

Project Number: AI089986

Grant PI: Kenneth Stuart, PhD

Researchers identified molecular signatures of divergent human immune responses to infections.
Shared Studies:
Transcriptional responses induced by controlled human malaria infection (CHMI)

SDY278 Optimization FACS panels

Description:
Human Anti-viral Immune Responses in Tissues and Circulation

Project Number: AI128949

Grant PI: Donna Farber, PhD

Researchers are obtaining in- depth profiles of how human innate and adaptive immune cells in tissues respond to viral infection, with a focus on the globally pervasive herpesvirus, Cytomegalovirus (CMV).

Integrative Omics of HepB Vaccine Response in Co-infection with Parasites

Project Number: AI128910

Grant PI: Elias Haddad, PhD

Researchers are developing immune models of the molecular and sub-network signatures that characterize host response to HepB vaccination from low to high helminth (parasitic worm) burden, by using bioinformatics and systems biology analyses.

System Biological Analyses of Innate and Adaptive Responses to Vaccination

Project Number: AI090023

Grant PI: Bali Pulendran, PhD

Researchers are utilizing systems level analysis to assess innate and adaptive responses to vaccination within elderly, infant, and transplant recipient populations. Results will support definition of molecular signatures that predict immunogenicity within these populations.
Shared Studies:
SDY984 Zoster Vaccine in Young and Elderly

SDY61 Systems Biology of 2007 Influenza Vaccination in Humans

SDY269 Systems Biology of 2008 Influenza Vaccination in Humans

SDY270 Systems Biology of 2009 Influenza Vaccination in Humans

Data Center: School of Medicine at Mount Sinai/University of California Berkeley
Description:
Dengue Human Immunology Project Consortium (DHIPC)

Project Number: AI118610

Grant PI: Ana Fernandez-Sesma, PhD

Researchers are utilizing cutting-edge systems biology techniques to study human immune responses 1) during or following dengue virus (DENV) infection, 2) before and after live attenuated DENV vaccination. Results will support identification of mechanisms underlying the human immune response to infection or vaccination against dengue, as well as of genetic factors
Shared Studies:
SDY1100 Project 3 - Optimization Experiments DCs DV2 and DV4 -- CyTOF

SDY1149 Project 3 - Optimization Experiments DCs DV2 and DV4 - MBAA

SDY1288 Comprehensive innate immune profiling of chikungunya virus infection in pediatric cases

Data Center: La Jolla Institute for Allergy and Immunology
Description:
Human Immune Signatures of Dengue Virus and Mycobacterium Tuberculosis Exposure in Infection, Disease and Vaccination

Project Number: AI118626

Grant PI: Alessandro Sette, PhD

Researchers are characterizing Immune Signatures (IMS) of T cell subsets associated with protection vs. susceptibility to severe disease following infection with Dengue virus (DENV) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and IMS associated with vaccination with DENV and MTB vaccines.
Shared Studies:
SDY1324 Transcriptomic Analysis of CD4+ T Cells Reveals Novel Immune Signatures of Latent Tuberculosis

SDY820 Human Immune Signature (Flow Cytometry) of Latent TB infection

SDY888 Human Immune Signature of Dengue Virus Infection

SDY1190 Single-cell RNA-Seq analysis of MTB and DENV immune responses

Description:
Mapping Immune Responses to CMV in Renal Transplant Recipients

Project Number: AI128913

Grant PI: Elaine Reed, PhD

Researchers are utilizing high-throughput systems biology technologies and novel statistical and computational approaches to characterize the innate and adaptive immune response to Cytomegalovirus (CMV) in the setting of solid organ transplantation.

Systems Immune Profiling of Divergent Responses to Infection

Project Number: AI089992

Grant PI: David Hafler, PhD and Ruth Montgomery, PhD

Researchers are leveraging a common experimental infrastructure to focus on several different infectious diseases: the Lyme disease spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, emerging arthropod-borne West Nile virus, and effects of aging on vaccination against influenza..

SDY517 Deciphering the role of Natural Killer cells in resistance to infection with West Nile virus

Description:
Bioinformatics Approach to Influenza A/H1N1 Vaccine Immune Profiling

Project Number: AI089859

Grant PI: Greg Poland, PhD

Researchers developed novel comprehensive immune profiles using a systems biology approach to define specific immune profiles that discriminate baseline, early, mid, and late (homeostatic) innate, humoral, and cellular immune responses after immunization among older adults.
Shared Studies:
SDY67 Bioinformatics Approach to 2010-2011 TIV Influenza A/H1N1 Vaccine Immune Profiling

Bioinformatics Approach to Influenza A/H1N1 Vaccine Immune Profiling

Grant PI: Ellis Reinherz, PhD

Researchers developed bionformatic tools to determine global variability of influenza A, an Infrastructure for analysis of sequence diversity and potential T cell epitopes and a database for vaccine development.
